{{pp-30-500|small=yes}} {{Use American English|date=February 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Amy Schumer | image = Amy Schumer by Mario Santor.jpg | caption = Schumer in 2011 | birth_name = Amy Beth Schumer | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1981|6|1}} | birth_place = [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], New York, U.S. | alma_mater = [[Towson University]] | medium = [[Stand-up comedy]], theatre, television, film | active = 2004–present | genre = [[Observational comedy]], [[blue comedy]], [[sketch comedy]], [[insult comedy]] | subject = [[Interpersonal relationship]]s, [[sex]], [[everyday life]], [[self-deprecation]] | spouse = {{marriage|Chris Fischer|2018}} | relatives = [[Chuck Schumer]] | website = {{URL|http://amyschumer.com}} }}
'''Amy Beth Schumer'''<ref name="tvg"/> (born June 1, 1981) is an American stand-up comedian and actress. She ventured into comedy in the early 2000s before appearing as a contestant on the [[Last Comic Standing 5|fifth season]] of the [[NBC]] reality competition series ''[[Last Comic Standing]]'' in 2007. Since 2013, she has been the creator, co-producer, co-writer, and star of the [[Comedy Central]] [[sketch comedy]] series ''[[Inside Amy Schumer]]'', for which she received a [[Peabody Award]] and for which Schumer has been nominated for five [[Primetime Emmy Award]]s, winning [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Variety Sketch Series|Outstanding Variety Sketch Series]] in 2015.
Schumer wrote and made her film debut in a starring role in ''[[Trainwreck (film)|Trainwreck]]'' (2015), for which she received nominations for the [[Writers Guild of America Award for Best Original Screenplay]] and the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Comedy or Musical]]. She published a memoir in 2016, ''[[The Girl with the Lower Back Tattoo]]'', which held the top position on [[List of The New York Times Non-Fiction Best Sellers|''The New York Times'' Non-Fiction Best Seller list]] for two weeks. The same year, she garnered two [[Grammy Awards|Grammy Award]] nominations for [[Grammy Award for Best Comedy Album|Best Comedy Album]] for ''[[Amy Schumer: Live at the Apollo]]'' and [[Grammy Award for Best Spoken Word Album|Best Spoken Word Album]] for ''The Girl with the Lower Back Tattoo''. In 2018, she starred in the comedy film ''[[I Feel Pretty (film)|I Feel Pretty]]'' and garnered a [[Tony Award for Best Actress in a Play]] nomination for her [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] debut in ''[[Meteor Shower (play)|Meteor Shower]]''.
== Early life and background == Schumer was born on June 1, 1981 on the [[Upper East Side]] of [[Manhattan]], New York,<ref name="tvg">{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/amy-schumer/289032/|title=Amy Schumer|work=[[TV Guide]]|accessdate=April 16, 2015|archivedate=September 19, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150919090055/http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/amy-schumer/289032}}</ref><ref name="npr">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=188698578|title='Inside Amy Schumer': It's Not Just Sex Stuff|publisher=NPR|date=June 25, 2013|accessdate=November 22, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160911045504/http://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=188698578|archivedate=September 11, 2016|deadurl=no|quote=...I was born on the Upper East Side...}}</ref> to Sandra Jane (née Jones) and Gordon David Schumer, who owned a baby-furniture company.<ref name="npr" /><ref>{{cite journal |last=Berlin |first=Erika |date=May 2012 |title=Big Mouth: Amy Schumer |journal=Rolling Stone |issue=1158 |page=56 |url= <!--|accessdate=September 13, 2012-->}}</ref><ref name=obitm>{{cite web|url=http://obits.dignitymemorial.com/dignity-memorial/obituary.aspx?n=Betty-Jones&lc=4467&pid=162651286&mid=5397704 |title=Betty Jane Jones Obituary: View Obituary for Betty Jane Jones by Florida Memorial Funeral Home, Rockledge, FL |publisher=Obits.dignitymemorial.com |date= |accessdate=April 25, 2014}}</ref> She later moved with her mother to Long Island, where she attended high school.<ref name=fdr1>Stated on ''[[Finding Your Roots]]'', December 19, 2017</ref> She has a younger sister, Kim Caramele, who is a comedy writer and a producer,<ref name="Chester">{{cite news|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2007-09-27/entertainment/0709260023_1_amy-schumer-comic-standing-nbc-last-comic|title=Stand up, be recognized|last=Chester|first=Aaron|work=The Baltimore Sun|accessdate=September 13, 2012|date=September 27, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://time.com/81141/heres-what-amy-schumer-thinks-about-everything/|title=Here's What Amy Schumer Thinks About Everything|last=Alter|first=Charlotte|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=April 29, 2014|accessdate=November 22, 2014}}</ref> and a half-brother, Jason Stein,<ref name=NYTJason>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/11/arts/music/jason-stein-puts-a-jazz-spin-on-the-stand-up-of-his-half-sister-amy-schumer.html|title=Jason Stein Puts a Jazz Spin on the Stand-Up of His Half-Sister Amy Schumer|first=Nate|last=Chinen | work = [[The New York Times]] | date=December 10, 2015 | accessdate=May 3, 2017|quote=Technically they’re half-siblings, though neither gives much thought to that distinction. Mr. Stein, whose parents divorced when he was 2, lived with his mother and stepfather, Amy’s father, on Long Island. (His biological father, with whom Jason spent weekends, died when the boy was 10.)}}</ref> who is a musician in Chicago, Illinois.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-03-06/entertainment/ct-ott-0308-luis-20130306_1_amy-schumer-comedy-ranks-tv-show|title=Interview: Amy Schumer calls Comedy Central show a dream come true|last=Gomez|first=Luis|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=March 6, 2013|accessdate=November 22, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160102014436/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-03-06/entertainment/ct-ott-0308-luis-20130306_1_amy-schumer-comedy-ranks-tv-show|archivedate=January 2, 2016|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/amy-schumer-73090|title=Amy Schumer|last=Fortune|first=Drew|publisher=[[The A.V. Club]]|date=October 3, 2012|accessdate=November 22, 2014}}</ref>
Schumer's father was born to a Jewish family from [[Ukraine]].<ref name="jtaamyschumeronlearning">{{cite news|last1=Dolsten|first1=Josefin|title=Amy Schumer on learning about her Jewish ancestors: ‘I think this will change me’|url=https://www.jta.org/2017/12/20/arts-entertainment/amy-schumer-on-learning-about-her-jewish-ancestors-i-think-this-will-change-me|accessdate=December 21, 2017|work=Jewish Telegraphic Agency|date=December 20, 2017}}</ref> He is a first cousin of U.S. Senator [[Chuck Schumer]].<ref name="nyt2013" /><ref>{{cite web|last=Molyneaux|first=Libby|title=Make Us Laugh, Funny Girl! |url=http://www.laweekly.com/2011-02-03/calendar/make-us-laugh-funny-girl-amy-schumer/|work=LA Weekly|accessdate=September 13, 2012|date=February 3, 2011 | quote=He is not my uncle, he is my dad's cousin, I don't even think they are first cousins.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/57703179/ns/msnbc-all_in_with_chris_hayes/| title= ''All In with Chris Hayes'' [transcript] | publisher=[[NBC News]]|quote=Today, Senator Chuck Schumer joined actress and comedian Amy Schumer, who also happens to be her second cousin once removed, to call for stronger background checks for gun buyers.|date=August 3, 2015 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150901025445/http://www.nbcnews.com/id/57703179/ns/msnbc-all_in_with_chris_hayes#.VeUTl7xViko | archivedate= September 1, 2015 | deadurl=no}} Requires clicking "Show more text" link.</ref> Her mother, who is from a Protestant background and deep New England roots, [[converted to Judaism]] before her marriage.<ref name=obitm/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.vogue.com/13444553/amy-schumer-july-2016-cover-memoir-girl-with-lower-back-tattoo/|title=Amy Schumer Doesn't Care If You Like Her—She's Changing the Game|last=Van Meter|first=Jonathan|work=Vogue|date=June 16, 2016|accessdate=August 17, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2015/10/17/449257414/play-ball-comedian-amy-schumer-plays-not-my-job|title=Play Ball! Comedian Amy Schumer Plays Not My Job|work=[[Wait Wait...Don't Tell Me!]]|publisher=[[National Public Radio]]|date=October 17, 2015|accessdate=January 4, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160911054918/http://www.npr.org/2015/10/17/449257414/play-ball-comedian-amy-schumer-plays-not-my-job|archivedate=September 11, 2016|deadurl=no}}</ref> Schumer was raised Jewish and says she had to deal with [[antisemitism]] as a child.<ref name="jtahappyhanukkah">{{cite news|last1=Keys|first1=Lisa|title=Amy Schumer sings: Happy Hanukkah!|url=http://www.jta.org/2015/12/08/news-opinion/the-telegraph/amy-schumer-sings-happy-hanukkah|work=Jewish Telegraphic Agency|date=December 8, 2015|accessdate=February 8, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.laughspin.com/2011/01/20/ass-kickin-amy-schumer-is-on-the-rise/ |title=Ass-kickin' Amy Schumer is on the rise |publisher=[[ServInt]] |website=Laughspin |date=January 20, 2011 |accessdate=April 25, 2014 |quote=That's a good question. I don't know. Judaism, for me, is just another area where I didn't feel accepted or like I belonged. I grew up on Long Island, but I grew up in the Irish Catholic mecca of Long Island. I've done some material on being Jewish onstage, and I talk about how the kids used to call me "Amy Jewmer." And I really did: even with the parents of my friends, there was a ton of anti-Semitism going on, openly and in front of me. When it went to college, it was the first time I wasn't apologizing for being Jewish, but there's definitely some residual shame that I grew up with because of it. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140110002012/http://www.laughspin.com/2011/01/20/ass-kickin-amy-schumer-is-on-the-rise/ |archivedate=January 10, 2014 |deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://ca.complex.com/pop-culture/2015/07/amy-schumer-trainwreck-interview |work=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]| title= Amy Schumer Does Not Need Your Approval | first=Rachel |last=Handler | date= July 2015 | quote=If a reference pops into my head I'll say it, but my experience of Judaism was this: I went to temple every Friday, and went to Sunday school, you know, Hebrew school, and then I had my [[Bar and Bat Mitzvah|Bat Mitzvah]], and then I think that might be the last time I was in a temple.|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150715123305/http://ca.complex.com/pop-culture/2015/07/amy-schumer-trainwreck-interview|archivedate=July 15, 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> Her mother's ancestry included [[Puritans]] in the 17th-century English colony of Massachusetts. As a guest on ''[[Finding Your Roots]]'' in 2017, Schumer learned that in 1704, three children from her ancestor Thomas Tarbell's family were captured at [[Groton, Massachusetts]] in a French-[[Abenaki]] raid and taken to [[Montreal]]. The girl was ransomed by a French-Canadian family and ultimately joined a French Catholic convent; the two boys were each adopted by Mohawk families at [[Kahnawake]] and became thoroughly assimilated.<ref name=fdr1/>
Through the success of her father's furniture company in Manhattan, Schumer's household was wealthy during her early years.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/jordanzakarin/amy-schumer-comedy-central-10-true-facts|title=10 Incredibly True Facts About Comedy Central's Amy Schumer, According To Amy Schumer|last=Zakarin|first=Jordan|work=[[BuzzFeed]]|date=July 2, 2013|accessdate=November 22, 2014}}</ref> When she was nine years old, her father's business failed and he went bankrupt, and either then<ref name="nyt2013" /> or when she was 12<ref name="enewsfarm">{{cite web| url= http://www.eonline.com/news/816988/amy-schumer-buys-her-father-s-farm-back-shares-the-news-with-an-adorable-home-video|title=Amy Schumer Buys Her Father's Farm Back, Shares the News With an Adorable Home Video| first= Kendall |last= Fisher|date= December 19, 2016 |accessdate= December 20, 2016|publisher=[[E! News]] | quote=Schumer's father was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis when she was just 12 years old.}}</ref> (sources differ), her father was diagnosed with [[multiple sclerosis]]. Some time afterward, her parents divorced.<ref name="nyt2013">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/21/arts/television/amy-schumers-comedy-central-show-from-the-inside.html?pagewanted=all |title=Amy Schumer, Funny Girl |work = [[The New York Times]] |date=April 18, 2013 |first=Jason |last=Zinoman |accessdate=November 21, 2014|quote=When Ms. Schumer was 9, her family went bankrupt and her father received a diagnosis of [[multiple sclerosis]]. Three years later her parents divorced. ... Ms. Schumer, who said she is second cousin to Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York.}}</ref> Moving to [[Long Island]] with her mother, Schumer lived in [[Rockville Centre, New York]] and attended [[South Side High School (Rockville Centre, New York)|South Side High School]]. She was voted both "Class Clown" and "Teacher's Worst Nightmare" upon graduation in 1999.<ref name="Razzano">{{cite web|url=http://www.qchron.com/qboro/stories/last-comic-comedienne-settles-in-astoria/article_4a60528f-3798-554d-98bc-d890c1c8ad22.html|title='Last Comic' Comedienne Settles In Astoria|last=Razzano|first=Tiffany|work=Queens Chronicle|date=May 15, 2008|accessdate=September 13, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6mtrCAiYz?url=http://www.qchron.com/qboro/stories/last-comic-comedienne-settles-in-astoria/article_4a60528f-3798-554d-98bc-d890c1c8ad22.html|archivedate=December 20, 2016|deadurl=no}} Note: Despite source's reference to ''Keeping Abreast'' as [[Off-Broadway]], it does not appear in the [[Internet Off-Broadway Database]].</ref> She attended the [[Hebrew school]] of the Central Synagogue of Nassau County, a [[Reform Judaism|Reform]] synagogue in Rockville Centre, on whose board her mother served.<ref name="jtachildhoodrabbi">{{cite news|last1=Kamin|first1=Debra|title=Amy Schumer's childhood rabbi dishes on her Hebrew school antics|url=http://www.jta.org/2015/07/22/life-religion/amy-schumers-childhood-rabbi-dishes-on-hebrew-school-antics|accessdate=February 7, 2016|work=Jewish Telegraphic Agency|date=July 22, 2015}}</ref><ref name="amyschumerschildhoodrabbiforward">{{cite news|last1=Landes|first1=Rachel X.|title=Amy Schumer's Childhood Rabbi Enjoyed 'Trainwreck'|url=http://forward.com/the-assimilator/312451/amy-schumers-rabbi/|accessdate=February 8, 2016|work=Forward|date=July 22, 2015|quote=In a personal blog post for the Religious News Service, Salkin wrote, that the Schumers were very involved in Jewish life — Amy's mother served on the temple board and chaired the education committee. Salkin officiated at Amy's older brother's bar mitzvah.}}</ref>
Schumer moved near [[Baltimore|Baltimore, Maryland]], after high school when she attended [[Towson University]]; she graduated with a degree in theater in 2003.<ref name="Chester" /><ref name="Razzano" /> She returned to New York City after college, where she studied at the [[William Esper Studio]] for two years and worked as a [[bartender]] and a waitress.<ref name="Razzano" />
== Career == After graduating with a degree in theater from [[Towson University]] in 2003 and moving to New York City, Schumer portrayed a young woman diagnosed with breast cancer in the [[Off-Off-Broadway]] black comedy ''Keeping Abreast''.<ref name="Razzano" /> She started doing stand-up comedy on June 1, 2004, when she first performed at [[Gotham Comedy Club]].<ref name="Scarpa">{{cite web|last=Scarpa|first=Gina|title=Exclusive Interview: Amy Schumer from 'Last Comic Standing'|url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/last-comic-standing/exclusive-interview-amy-schume-10735.aspx|publisher=BuddyTV.com|accessdate=September 13, 2012|date=September 12, 2007}}</ref> In 2007, she recorded a ''[[Live at Gotham]]'' episode for [[Comedy Central]] before appearing on ''[[Last Comic Standing]]''; she later recalled that she thought of the episode as her "big break."<ref>{{cite web|last=Lerman|first=Ali|title=Amy Schumer Didn't Win 'Last Comic Standing' But She Is The One Getting the Last Laugh|url= http://blogs.ocweekly.com/heardmentality/2012/08/amy_schumer_didnt_win_last_com.php|work=OC Weekly|accessdate= September 13, 2012|date=August 8, 2012|archivedate=September 20, 2012|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120920065132/http://blogs.ocweekly.com/heardmentality/2012/08/amy_schumer_didnt_win_last_com.php|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
[[File:Amy Schumer.jpg|thumb|left|Schumer performing in 2006|266x266px]] Rebounding from an unsuccessful audition for an earlier season,<ref>{{cite web |last=Sadowski |first=Michael |title=Laugh it up: Comic comes to conquer Caesars |url=http://www.poconorecord.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070918/NEWS/709180302/-1/News |work=Pocono Record |accessdate=September 13, 2012 |date=September 18, 2007 |quote=It was the second time I auditioned for it. The first time they said I hadn't been around long enough, but I made it the second time I auditioned.}}</ref> she advanced to the finals of the [[Last Comic Standing 5|fifth season]] of the NBC reality television talent show ''Last Comic Standing'' and placed fourth.<ref name="Scarpa" /> Schumer said in April 2011, "''Last Comic'' was totally fun. I had a great time because there was no pressure on me; I had been doing stand-up around two years. I wasn't supposed to do well. So every time I advanced it was a happy surprise. I kept it honest on the show and it served me well."<ref name="Shariat">{{cite web|last=Shariat|first=Zhila|title=Dirty Hard Laughs with Comedian Amy Schumer|url=http://www.serialoptimist.com/interviews/dirty-hard-laughs-with-comedian-amy-schumer-4546.html|work=Serial Optimist|accessdate=September 13, 2012|date=April 22, 2011}}</ref>
Schumer co-starred in the Comedy Central reality show ''[[Reality Bites Back]]'' in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/feb/09/inside-amy-schumer-judd-apatow|title=Amy Schumer: 'It's fun to exorcise my demons'|work=[[The Guardian]]|first=Rachel|last=Aroesti|date=February 9, 2015|accessdate=October 6, 2015}}</ref> In 2009, she appeared in an advertising campaign for [[Butterfinger]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Elliott|first=Stuart|title=Butterfinger Hopes Funny Again Means Money|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/08/business/media/08adnewsletter1.html?pagewanted=all|work=The New York Times|accessdate=September 13, 2012|date=September 8, 2009}}</ref> Schumer was a recurring guest on [[Fox News Channel|Fox News]] late-night program ''[[Red Eye w/ Greg Gutfeld]]'' between 2007 and 2012. Her first [[Comedy Central Presents]] special aired on April 2, 2010. She served as a co-host of ''A Different Spin with Mark Hoppus'' in 2011, later titled ''[[Hoppus on Music]]''.<ref name="Shariat" /> She has also written for ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]''.<ref name="Shariat" />
Schumer did an episode (#154) of ''[[WTF with Marc Maron]]'' podcast on March 3, 2011, in which she discusses her early life in more detail.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wtfpod.com/podcast/episodes/episode_154_-_amy_schumer |title=WTF with Marc Maron Podcast – Episode 154 – Amy Schumer |website=[[WTF with Marc Maron]] |date=March 3, 2011|accessdate=April 25, 2014}}</ref> Schumer has appeared in roles on the NBC comedy series ''[[30 Rock]]'', the [[Adult Swim]] mockumentary series ''[[Delocated]]'', and the two HBO series, ''[[Curb Your Enthusiasm]]'' and ''[[Girls (TV series)|Girls]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Rose|first=Lacey|title=Comedienne Amy Schumer Adds Comedy CD, TV Guest Roles| url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/comedienne-amy-schumer-adds-comedy-182296|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=September 13, 2012|date=April 26, 2011}}</ref>
She acted in three films in 2012: the independent comedy ''Price Check'', the comedy-drama ''[[Seeking a Friend for the End of the World]]'', and the independent comedy ''Sleepwalk with Me''.<ref name="Geurts">{{cite web |last=Geurts |first=Jimmy |title=Amy Schumer talks career and ''Cutting'' comedy |url= http://cltampa.com/dailyloaf/archives/2012/04/19/amy-schumer-talks-career-and-cutting-comedy |work=Creative Loafing |accessdate=September 13, 2012 |date=April 19, 2012}}</ref> Schumer also appeared on ''The [[Comedy Central Roast]] of [[Charlie Sheen]]'' in September 2011, and ''The Comedy Central Roast of [[Roseanne Barr]]'' in August 2012. [[File:Amy Schumer SXSW One.jpg|thumb|Schumer at [[South by Southwest]] in 2015|279x279px]] Schumer released a standup comedy album, ''Cutting'', in 2011.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.avclub.com/article/the-best-comedy-albums-of-2011-66251 |title= The best comedy albums of 2011|author=Various| date= December 8, 2011 | publisher=The A.V. Club |accessdate= February 14, 2016| archivedate= February 5, 2016 | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160205110817/http://www.avclub.com/article/the-best-comedy-albums-of-2011-66251 | deadurl=no }}</ref> Her standup comedy special ''Mostly Sex Stuff'' premiered on [[Comedy Central]] on August 18, 2012, to positive reviews.<ref>{{cite web|last= Daniel|first=Berkowitz|title=Amy Schumer Mostly Sex Stuff special review|url=http://www.thespittake.com/2012/08/16/amy-schumer-mostly-sex-stuff-comedy-central-2/|publisher=TheSpitTake.com|accessdate=April 10, 2013}}</ref> Schumer said in February 2012, "I don't like the [[observational comedy|observational]] stuff. I like tackling the stuff nobody else talks about, like the darkest, most serious thing about yourself. I talk about life and sex and personal stories and stuff everybody can relate to, and some can't."<ref>{{cite web|last=Johnson|first=Kevin C.|title=Q&A: Amy Schumer's 'Cutting' comedy act is coming to Lumière| url= http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/music/q-a-amy-schumer-s-cutting-comedy-act-is-coming/article_764ff69d-6370-51a7-b0af-4cafbff73de0.html| work=[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]] |accessdate= September 13, 2012|date=February 10, 2012}}</ref>
In June 2012, Schumer began work on a [[sketch comedy]] series for Comedy Central. The show features single-camera vignettes of Schumer playing "heightened versions" of herself. The vignettes are linked together with footage of Schumer's stand-up.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2012/06/28/comedy-central-greenlights-three-new-series-for-2013-starring-comedians-amy-schumer-and-anthony-jeselnik-and-the-ben-show-starring-ben-hoffman/139786/|title=Comedy Central Greenlights Three New Series for 2013 Starring Comedians Amy Schumer and Anthony Jeselnik and 'The Ben Show' Starring Ben Hoffman|last=Bibel|first=Sara|publisher=[[TV by the Numbers]]|date=June 28, 2012|accessdate=June 28, 2012}}</ref> The show, ''[[Inside Amy Schumer]]'', premiered on Comedy Central on April 30, 2013. ''Inside Amy Schumer'' was picked up for a second season that began in 2014. A behind-the-scenes miniseries entitled ''Behind Amy Schumer'' premiered in 2012. The third season premiered on April 21, 2015, with a fourth season ordered the same day.<ref>{{cite web|title='Inside Amy Schumer' Renewed for Fourth Season by Comedy Central|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2015/04/20/inside-amy-schumer-renewed-for-fourth-season-by-comedy-central/392102/|publisher=[[TV by the Numbers]]|last=Kondolojy|first=Amanda|accessdate=April 21, 2015|date=April 20, 2015}}</ref>
In 2014, Schumer embarked on her ''Back Door Tour'' to promote the second season of her show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.laughspin.com/2013/12/03/comedy-central-announces-the-inside-amy-schumers-back-door-tour/ |title=Comedy Central announces the Inside Amy Schumer's Back Door Tour |website=LaughSpin |date=December 3, 2013 |accessdate=April 25, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140409173344/http://www.laughspin.com/2013/12/03/comedy-central-announces-the-inside-amy-schumers-back-door-tour/ |archivedate=April 9, 2014 }}</ref> The show featured closing act [[Bridget Everett]], whom Schumer cites as her favorite live performer.<ref>{{cite news|last=Langmuir |first=Molly |url=http://nymag.com/news/intelligencer/encounter/bridget-everett-2013-12/ |title=129 Minutes With Bridget Everett |work= [[New York (magazine)|New York]]|date=November 24, 2013 |accessdate=April 25, 2014}}</ref> She also appeared as a guest on an episode of comedian [[Jerry Seinfeld]]'s Internet series ''[[Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee]]'' in 2014.<ref>{{cite news |last=O'Connell |first=Ryan |date=November 13, 2014 |title=Jerry Seinfeld's Ferrari Breaks Down in 'Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee' With Amy Schumer |url=http://www.thewrap.com/jerry-seinfelds-ferrari-breaks-down-in-comedians-in-cars-getting-coffee-with-amy-schumer-video/ |newspaper=The Wrap}}</ref>
She hosted the 2015 MTV Movie Awards, which took place on April 11.<ref>{{cite news |last=Mallenbaum |first=Carly |date=April 12, 2015 |title=Amy Schumer's Best Jokes at the MTV Movie Awards |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2015/04/12/amy-schumer-jokes-mtv-music-awards/25695701/ |newspaper=USA Today}}</ref> Schumer wrote and played her first leading film role in ''[[Trainwreck (film)|Trainwreck]]'', co-starring [[Bill Hader]], which was released on July 17, 2015.<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Foundas |first=Scott |date=March 16, 2015 |title=Amy Schumer and Judd Apatow Craft a Winning Portrait of a Good-Time Sally in the Grip of Her First Serious Relationship |url=https://variety.com/2015/film/reviews/sxsw-film-review-trainwreck-1201453443/ |magazine=Variety}}</ref>
In August 2015, [[Jennifer Lawrence]] said she and Schumer planned to co-star in a film for which they and Schumer's sister Kim were co-writing a screenplay.<ref>{{cite news | work =The New York Times|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/08/26/jennifer-lawrence-amy-schumer-writing-screenplay-together/| title=Jennifer Lawrence, Amy Schumer Writing Screenplay Together|first= Brooks|last=barnes|date= August 26, 2015|accessdate=September 1, 2015}}</ref> Schumer performed as opening act for [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] on three New York City dates of the singer's [[Rebel Heart Tour]] in September 2015.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jun/19/amy-schumer-open-madonna-rebel-heart-tour-new-york|title=Amy Schumer to open for Madonna on Rebel Heart tour in New York|last=Mokoena|first=Tshepo|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=June 19, 2015|accessdate=September 1, 2015}}</ref>
On October 17, 2015, Schumer's comedy special ''[[Amy Schumer: Live at the Apollo]]'' premiered on [[HBO]].<ref name="apollo">{{cite web|url=http://www.hbo.com/comedy/amy-schumer-live-from-the-apollo|title=Amy Schumer: Live at the Apollo|publisher=HBO|accessdate=October 17, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2015/10/amy-schumer-live-at-the-apollo-review.html|title=Amy Schumer: Live at the Apollo Review|work=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]|first=Garrett|last=Martin|date=October 16, 2015|accessdate=October 17, 2015}}</ref> In 2016, it was nominated for three [[Primetime Emmy Award]]s for Outstanding Variety Special, Writing, and Directing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/awards/nominees-winners/2016/outstanding-variety-music-or-comedy-special|title=2016 Primetime Emmy Awards – Variety Special Nominees/Winners|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[Emmy Award|Primetime Emmy Awards]]|accessdate=July 16, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/awards/nominees-winners/2016/outstanding-writing-for-a-variety-special|title=2016 Primetime Emmy Awards – Variety Special Nominees/Winners|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[Emmy Award|Primetime Emmy Awards]]|accessdate=July 16, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/awards/nominees-winners/2016/outstanding-directing-for-a-variety-special|title=2016 Primetime Emmy Awards – Variety Special Nominees/Winners|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[Emmy Award|Primetime Emmy Awards]]|accessdate=July 16, 2016}}</ref> It also garnered her a nomination for the [[Grammy Award for Best Comedy Album]].<ref name="grammy">https://www.eonline.com/news/813990/amy-schumer-nominated-for-the-2017-grammys-see-more-of-the-most-unlikely-grammy-award-winners-of-all-time</ref>
On June 23, 2016, during her sold out performance at Madison Square Garden, Schumer announced her first world tour starting on August 26 in Dublin.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/entertainthis/2016/06/24/amy-schumer-world-comedy-tour-dates/86337832|title=Amy Schumer is taking her comedy tour around the world|work=[[USA Today]]|first=Maeve|last=Mcdermott|date=June 24, 2016|accessdate=June 26, 2016}}</ref> Also that year, Schumer wrote a memoir, entitled ''[[The Girl with the Lower Back Tattoo]]''.<ref name="voguereadanexcerptfrom">{{cite news|title=Read an Excerpt From Amy Schumer's Upcoming Book, The Girl with the Lower Back Tattoo|url=http://www.vogue.com/13447204/amy-schumer-book-excerpt-the-girl-with-the-lower-back-tattoo/|accessdate=August 13, 2016|work=Vogue}}</ref> It held the top position on [[List of The New York Times Non-Fiction Best Sellers|''The New York Times'' Non-Fiction Best Seller list]] for two weeks in September 2016 and garnered her a nomination for the [[Grammy Award for Best Spoken Word Album]].<ref name="grammy"/><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/best-sellers/2016/09/11/combined-print-and-e-book-nonfiction/ | title=Combined Print & E-Book Nonfiction | work=[[The New York Times]] | accessdate=September 9, 2016 | date=September 11, 2016}}</ref>
Schumer made her [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] debut in 2017 with [[Steve Martin]]'s comedy play ''[[Meteor Shower (play)|Meteor Shower]]'', about two couples in 1993 who spend an evening with each other.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/07/theater/amy-schumer-steve-martin-broadway-meteor-shower.html?action=click&contentCollection=Theater&module=RelatedCoverage&region=EndOfArticle&pgtype=article | title=Amy Schumer to Make Broadway Debut in New Steve Martin Play | work=[[The New York Times]] | accessdate=November 30, 2017 | date=August 7, 2017}}</ref> Her performance received acclaim and garnered her a nomination for the [[Tony Award for Best Actress in a Play]]. In 2018, she starred in the comedy film ''[[I Feel Pretty (film)|I Feel Pretty]]''.
[[Spotify]] released the original podcast ''Amy Schumer Presents: 3 Girls, 1 Keith'' on June 21, 2018, starring Schumer and her best comedy friends [[Rachel Feinstein (comedian)|Rachel Feinstein]], [[Bridget Everett]] and [[Keith Robinson (comedian)|Keith Robinson]] as they talk about comedy, pop culture, politics and their personal lives.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://open.spotify.com/show/2UtdM2mvBQesTqGTyiKn8w?utm_source=us-en_brand_contextual_text&utm_medium=paidsearch&utm_campaign=alwayson_ucanz_us_performancemarketing_amyschumer_brand+contextual+text+exact+us-en+google&gclid=EAIaIQobChMI-Jq9sviU3AIVlonICh0DSQnAEAAYASAAEgIHTPD_BwE&gclsrc=aw.ds&dclid=COD-orT4lNwCFVVBDAodeysF-w | title=Amy Schumer Presents: 3 Girls, 1 Keith | work=[[Spotify]] | accessdate=July 10, 2018 | date=June 6, 2018}}</ref>

== In the media == [[File:Ms. magazine Cover - Summer 2015.jpg|thumb|Schumer on the cover of [[Ms. (magazine)|''Ms.'' magazine]] in 2015|244x244px]] In 2015, Schumer was named one of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine's [[Time 100|100 most influential people]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://time.com/3823137/amy-schumer-2015-time-100/|title=Amy Schumer|work=TIME|date=April 16, received praise for addressing various social issues through comedy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/inside-amy-schumer-go-behind-the-scenes-of-that-incredible-12-angry-men-homage-20150505|title='Inside Amy Schumer': Go Behind the Scenes of That Incredible '12 Schumer|work=Variety|first=Julie|last=Seabaugh|date=January 6, 2014|accessdate=September 28, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/tv/opinion/the-misunderstood-genius-of-amy-schumer-1201491658/|title=The Misunderstood Genius of Amy Schumer|work=Variety|first=Andrew|last=Wallenstein|date=May 10, 2015|accessdate=September 28, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/12/movies/the-sneaky-power-of-amy-schumer-in-trainwreck-and-elsewhere.html|title=The Sneaky Power of Amy Schumer, in 'Trainwreck' and Elsewhere|work=The New York Times|first=Melena|last=Ryzik|date=July 8, 2015|accessdate=September 28, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/06/30/opinions/obeidallah-schumer-latino-joke/|title=Amy Schumer is no Donald Trump|publisher=CNN|first=Dean|last=Obeidallah|date=June 30, 2015|accessdate=September 28, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Heisey">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/jun/28/amy-schumer-comedys-viral-queen|title=Amy Schumer: comedy's viral queen|first=Monica|last=Heisey|work=The Guardian|date=June 28, 2015|accessdate=September 28, 2015}}</ref> In June 2015, Monica Heisey of ''[[The Guardian]]'' criticized her for "a shockingly large blind spot around race."<ref name=Heisey/> Schumer responded on Twitter, stating "I go in and out of playing an irreverent idiot. That includes making dumb jokes involving race... You can call it a 'blind spot for racism' or 'lazy,' but you are wrong. It is a joke ... I am not racist."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/06/29/entertainment/amy-schumer-racist-response-thr-feat/|title=Amy Schumer fires back at critics: 'I am not racist'|date=June 29, 2015|publisher=CNN}}</ref>
Throughout 2015, several of Schumer's skits in ''Inside Amy Schumer'' went [[Viral video|viral]] online, sparking [[think piece]]s regarding sex, feminism, and [[rape culture]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/jun/28/amy-schumer-comedys-viral-queen|title=Amy Schumer: comedy's viral queen|last=Heisey|first=Monica|date=June 28, 2015|newspaper=The Guardian|issn=0261-3077|access-date=April 25, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://stylecaster.com/beauty/beauty-buzz-amy-schumers-no-makeup-sketch-went-viral/|title=Beauty Buzz: Amy Schumer's No Makeup Sketch Went Viral, Super Fast Workouts, More|website=StyleCaster|accessdate=April 25, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cheatsheet.com/entertainment/why-everyone-is-talking-about-amy-schumer.html/?a=viewall|title=Why Everyone Is Talking About Amy Schumer|website=The Cheat Sheet|accessdate=April 25, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/2015/04/22/the_media_decides_when_youre_no_longer_believably_fkable_amy_schumer_tears_into_industry_sexism/|title="The media decides when you're no longer believably f**kable": Amy Schumer tears into industry sexism|last=Gorenstein|first=Colin|work=Salon|accessdate=April 25, 2016}}</ref>
After [[2015 Lafayette shooting|a fatal shooting]] took place at a showing of ''Trainwreck'' in [[Louisiana]], Schumer advocated for stricter [[gun control]] laws and increased mental health funding.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thinkprogress.org/culture/2015/08/03/3687189/amy-schumer-joins-her-cousin-sen-chuck-schumer-to-call-for-stronger-gun-laws-mental-health-funding/|title=Amy Schumer Joins Her Cousin Sen. Chuck Schumer to Call for Stronger Gun Laws, Mental Health Funding|last=Goldstein|first=Jessica|work=[[ThinkProgress]]|date=August 3, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151009064033/http://thinkprogress.org/culture/2015/08/03/3687189/amy-schumer-joins-her-cousin-sen-chuck-schumer-to-call-for-stronger-gun-laws-mental-health-funding/|archivedate=October 9, 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref>
In November 2015, Schumer posed nude for a photo by photographer [[Annie Leibovitz]] for 2016 edition of the [[Pirelli Calendar]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/11/30/amy-schumer-poses-nude-the-radical-power-of-her-beautiful-gross-photo.html|title=Amy Schumer Poses Nude: The Radical Power of Her 'Beautiful, Gross' Photo|last=Fallon|first=Kevin|work=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=November 30, 2015|accessdate=November 30, 2015}}</ref> Schumer tweeted the photo, writing "Beautiful, gross, strong, thin, fat, pretty, ugly, sexy, disgusting, flawless, woman. Thank you."<ref>{{cite web|title = Amy Schumer on Twitter|url = https://twitter.com/amyschumer/status/671353092630253569|publisher = Twitter|date=November 30, 2015|accessdate=November 30, 2015}}</ref>
In January 2016, Schumer was accused of stealing jokes from comedians [[Tammy Pescatelli]], [[Kathleen Madigan]], [[Wendy Liebman]], and [[Patrice O'Neal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2016/01/amy-schumer-joke-stealing-accusations-lie-detector|title=Amy Schumer Says She'd Take a Lie-Detector Test to Prove She Didn't Steal Jokes|work=Vanity Fair|first=Jeff|last=Bottari|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=February 4, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/01/21/amy-schumer-tammy-pescatelli-joke-stealing|title=Tammy Pescatelli apologizes for accusing Amy Schumer of joke stealing|work=Entertainment Weekly|first=Will|last=Robinson|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=February 4, 2016}}</ref> Schumer denied the allegations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/article/amy-schumer-joke-theft-allegation|title=Amy Schumer Denies Joke Stealing, Accuses Comedian Tammy Pescatelli of 'Trying to Get Something Going'|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|first=Karen|last=MizoguchiI|date=January 20, 2016|accessdate=February 4, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2016/01/amy-schumer-responds-to-joke-theft-accusations.html|title=Amy Schumer Responds to Joke-Theft Accusations: 'I Have Never and Would Never Steal a Joke.'|work=[[New York (magazine)|Vulture]]|first=Jackson|last=McHenry|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=February 4, 2016}}</ref> Other comedians, such as [[Marc Maron]] and [[Dave Rubin]], stood up for Schumer.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/2016/1/30/10874906/marc-maron-amy-schumer|title=Marc Maron stands up for Amy Schumer: "This isn't about justice, it's about hate."|work=[[Vox (website)|Vox]]|first=Alex|last=Abad-Santos|date= January 30, 2016|accessdate=February 4, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/01/22/is-amy-schumer-really-a-joke-thief.html|title=Is Amy Schumer Really a Joke Thief?|work=The Daily Beast|first=Lizzie|last=Crocker|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=February 4, 2016}}</ref> Pescatelli later apologized, stating it had "gone too far" and was probably "parallel thinking".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/article/tammy-pescatelli-apologizes-amy-schumer-joke-stealing|title=Comedian Tammy Pescatelli Apologizes for Accusing Amy Schumer of Joke Stealing: 'She Has Every Right to Be Mad'|work=People|first=Jodi|last=Guglielmi|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=February 4, 2016}}</ref>

news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/23/amy-schumer-wwe-dolph-ziggler-sex-too-athletic_n_1825039.html|title=Amy Schumer, Comedian, On Breakup With WWE's Dolph Ziggler: 'The Sex Was Too 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> and comedian [[Anthony Jeselnik]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cosmopolitan.com/entertainment/celebs/news/a4341/amy-schumer-interview/|title=''Inside Amy Schumer:'' Realer
